pr_title: Drop Array, Reference, Number, Integer and DoubleValue

timeline.message: Drop Array, Reference, Number, Integer and DoubleValue
Drop Array, Reference, Number, Integer and DoubleValue

timeline.bodyText:
If a caller other than wrapObject calls wrap on a Map<String, Object> this will return the wrong type.
It seems like this should parse the query value then check the type and wrap appropriately (or call FieldValue.valueOf). That would also mean that wrapObject wouldn't have change below.
timeline.author: wilhuff

replies.bodyText: Fixed.  This conversion should go away entirely in a follow-up PR too.
replies.author: schmidt-sebastian

timeline.author: wilhuff

replies.bodyText:
Only ArrayContainsFilter does the check right at the callsite. All other filters verify the value in the constructor, which is IMHO the better thing to do since the assert will include a stacktrace that should indicate where the incorrect value was created.
Furthermore, ArrayTransformOperation doesn't have a Value, it only operates on ArrayValue.Builder. For that reason, I left this as is for now.
replies.author: schmidt-sebastian

timeline.bodyText:
While we're fixing the format here, should we separate these values with something?
(Optional; may not be worth it. Just a thought because it may make these more readable.)
timeline.author: wilhuff
wilhuff

timeline.bodyText: This seems like something we could store as a field. It doesn't change for every document we match.
timeline.author: wilhuff

timeline.bodyText: Similarly we could do this conversion once in the constructor and keep a list of document keys as a field.
timeline.author: wilhuff

replies.bodyText: Done. This simplifies the code a bit since I can now use List.contains().
replies.author: schmidt-sebastian

timeline.bodyText: Nit: Java doesn't tend to abbreviate like this. Consider naming this just element, or haystackElement if you want to preserve the binding to the haystack.
timeline.author: wilhuff
